content.description:
Brass Pendant of St. Anthony of Padua Created in Kongo

The pendant depicts Saint Anthony standing and wearing a Catholic monk’s habit.
In his right hand, Saint Anthony holds a cross.
In his left hand, Saint Anthony holds a small figure, possibly an infant.
The pendant’s sheen suggests it is made of metal.
Gift of Ernst Anspach, 1999. The Metropolitan Museum of Art.
content.question: Which of the following statements best explains a connection between the pendant in the image and enslaved Africans in the Americas?

choices.label: By depicting a saint important in Portugal, the pendant indicates how the Kingdom of Kongo was forced to convert to Christianity and explains why enslaved people in the Americas rejected the faith.
The use of brass to manufacture the pendant highlights the role of the brass trade in initially attracting Europeans to West Africa, which became a major source of enslaved people in the Americas.
A pendant of a Roman Catholic saint created in the Kingdom of Kongo suggests that many West Central Africans were Christians before they arrived in the Americas as enslaved people.
A Christian pendant made by Africans provides evidence of the export of African manufactured goods to the Americas to support the veneration of ancestors by enslaved people.

content.answer: A pendant of a Roman Catholic saint created in the Kingdom of Kongo suggests that many West Central Africans were Christians before they arrived in the Americas as enslaved people.
